key_points: In 1968, then-Maj. Colin Powell was on his second tour in Vietnam, assigned to the Army’s 23rd Infantry Division.
Previously wounded in 1963 by a VC booby trap, Powell had already demonstrated resilience and commitment.
On Nov. 16, 1968, the helicopter carrying Powell and others crashed.
Injured but not deterred, Powell ran back to the burning wreckage multiple times to rescue fellow passengers.
He notably tore away burning metal with his bare hands to free a trapped passenger.
Powell was awarded the Soldier’s Medal for his heroism during the incident.
Over his deployments to Vietnam, Powell was also honored with a Bronze Star and two Purple Hearts.
The story highlights Powell's incredible bravery and dedication under extreme conditions.
This account was shared by Powell during an interview with the Academy of Achievement.
We Are The Mighty (WATM), a platform celebrating military life and service, shared this story.
